THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        
        Anthony L. Miller, Jr., Plaintiff,
        
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        
          Rashid Michael Aiken, Defendant.
          
        
      
    
  


CERTIFIED QUESTIONS

Opinion No. 25976
Heard April 5, 2005 - Filed May 2, 2005

CERTIFIED QUESTIONS ANSWERED


  
    
      
        
          William G. Jenkins, Jr., of Hilton Head Island, for Plaintiff.
        
      
    
  


  
    
      
        Max G. Mahaffee, of Grimball & Cabaniss, L.L.C., of Charleston, for Defendant.
      
    
  


JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  Pursuant to Rule 228, SCACR, we accepted the following questions on certification from the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina:


  
    I. 
    Is an automobile insurer which provides only non-liability  “collision and other named perils” coverage an “automobile insurance carrier” under S.C. Code Ann. § 38-77-160 (2002), and thus required to offer underinsured motorist (UIM) coverage?
  
  
    II.  
    If such an insurer is required to make an offer of UIM coverage, and no such offer was made, does the UIM coverage imposed by South Carolina law extend to the limits of a separate (though simultaneously obtained) liability policy?
  

FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKROUND
The plaintiff was injured in an automobile accident.Â  Plaintiff was a passenger in a car being driven by the defendant.Â  Defendant was at fault in causing the accident.Â  Plaintiff has suffered damages which exceed the extent of all coverages which could be applicable.
At the time of the accident, Plaintiff was residing with his father, who owned and operated a tractor-trailer that was not involved in the accident.Â  Plaintiffâ€™s father obtained non-trucking insurance on the tractor-trailer from two separate companies, but through a single agent.Â  The insurance consisted of:Â  (1) liability coverage up to $500,000 from Connecticut Indemnity Co. and (2) collision coverage up to $18,000 from Occidental Fire & Casualty Company.Â  Neither Connecticut nor Occidental offered UIM coverage to Plaintiffâ€™s father.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In answering a certified question raising a novel question of law, the Court is free to decide the question based on its assessment of which answer and reasoning would best comport with the law and public policies of this state and the Courtâ€™s sense of law, justice, and right.Â  See Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 411, 526 S.E.2d 716, 719 (2000) (citing S.C. Const. art. V, Â§Â§ 5 and 9, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-320 and -330 (1976 & Supp. 2004), and S.C. Code Ann Â§ 14-8-200 (Supp. 2004)); Osprey, Inc. v. Cabana Ltd. Partnership, 340 S.C. 367, 372, 532 S.E.2d 269, 272 (2000) (same); Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 378, 529 S.E.2d 528, 533 (2000) (same); Antley v. New York Life Ins. Co., 139 S.C. 23, 30, 137 S.E. 199, 201 (1927) (â€œIn [a] state of conflict between the decisions, it is up to the court to â€˜choose ye this day whom ye will serveâ€™; and, in the duty of this decision, the court has the right to determine which doctrine best appeals to its sense of law, justice, and right.â€).

  LAW/ANALYSIS

  Plaintiff argues an automobile insurer which provides only collision insurance, is an â€œautomobile insurance carrierâ€ under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-160, and is thus required to offer UIM coverage.Â Â  Section 38-77-160 provides, in relevant part: 


  Automobile insurance carriers shall offer, at the option of the  insured, uninsured motorist coverage up to the limits of the insuredâ€™s liability coverage in addition to the mandatory coverage prescribed in Section 38-77-150.Â  Such carriers shall also offer, at the option of the insured, underinsured motorist coverage up to the limits of the insured liability coverage to provide coverage in the event that damages are sustained in excess of the liability limits carried by an at-fault insured or underinsured motorist or in excess of any damages cap or limitation imposed by statute.

(emphasis added).Â  
The question we must decide is whether an insurer which provides only non-liability â€œcollision and other named perilsâ€ coverage constitutes an â€œautomobile insurance carrierâ€ under Section 38-77-160.
The cardinal rule of statutory interpretation is to ascertain and effectuate the intention of the Legislature.Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000).Â  In ascertaining the intent of the Legislature, a court should not focus on any single section or provision but should consider the language of the statute as a whole.Â  Mid-State Automotive Auction of Lexington, Inc. v. Altman, 324 S.C. 65, 69, 476 S.E.2d 690, 692 (1996).Â  When a statuteâ€™s terms are clear and unambiguous on their face, there is no room for statutory construction and a court must apply the statute according to its literal meaning.Â  Carolina Power & Light Co. v. City of Bennettsville, 314 S.C. 137, 139, 442 S.E.2d 177, 179 (1994).Â  However plain the ordinary meaning of the words used in a statute may be, the courts will reject that meaning when to accept it would lead to a result so plainly absurd that it could not possibly have been intended by the Legislature or would defeat the plain legislative intention.Â  Kiriakides v. United Artists Communications, Inc., 312 S.C. 271, 275, 440 S.E.2d 364, 366 (1994).Â  If possible, the court will construe the statute so as to escape the absurdity and carry the intention into effect. Id.
The term â€œautomobile insurance carrierâ€ is not defined in the pertinent South Carolina statutes.Â  South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-30(1) (2002) defines â€œautomobile insuranceâ€ as follows:

  â€œAutomobile insuranceâ€ means automobile bodily injury and  property damage liability insurance, including medical payments, and uninsured motorist coverage, and automobile physicalÂ  damage, collision, fire, theft, combined additional coverage, and similar automobile physical damage insurance and economic loss benefits as provided by this chapter written or offered by automobile insurers.Â Â Â Â  

(emphasis added).Â  
Plaintiff urges us to conclude that because Section 38-77-30(1) specifically includes â€œcollisionâ€ and other perils insurance, an automobile insurer providing only non-liability â€œcollision and other named perilsâ€ coverage is an â€œautomobile insurance carrierâ€ under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-160 and is required to offer UIM coverage.Â  
Plaintiff also cites Davis v. Budget & Control Bd., 298 S.C. 135, 378 S.E.2d 604 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  The issue in Davis was whether the State Insurance Reserve Fund must offer UIM coverage to those state agencies and political subdivisions to which it provides motor vehicle liability coverage.Â  The Court of Appeals considered whether the State Insurance Reserve Fund is an â€œautomobile insurance carrierâ€ under Section 38-77-160 and stated the following:
The term â€œautomobile insurance carrierâ€ is not defined by statute.Â  However, read in the context of other statutes in pari materia, it is clearly synonymous with the terms â€œinsurerâ€ and â€œautomobile insurer.â€ . . . Section 38-77-30(2) . . . defines â€œautomobile insurerâ€ to mean â€œan insurer licensed to do business in South Carolina and authorized to issue automobile insurance policies.â€Â  Section 38-1-20(25) . . . defines â€œinsurerâ€ to include

   any corporation, fraternal organization, . . . other association, partnership, society, order, individual, orÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  aggregation of individuals engaging or proposing orÂ Â Â Â Â Â  attempting to engage as principals in any kind of insurance or surety business . . . .

Davis, 298 S.C. at 137-138, 378 S.E.2d at 606-607.
The Court of Appeals concluded the State Insurance Reserve Fund did not fall under either definition and thus was not required to offer UIM coverage.[1] Plaintiff argues, that unlike the State Insurance Reserve Fund, Occidental is an automobile insurance carrier because Occidental admits it is an automobile insurer.Â  Therefore, Occidental was required to offer UIM coverage.Â  We agree Occidental is an automobile insurance carrier.Â  However, we conclude an automobile insurer providing only collision insurance to its insured should not be required to make a meaningful offer of UIM.Â  
First, to accept Plaintiffâ€™s argument requiring an insurer providing only collision insurance to make a meaningful offer of UIM would lead to a result so plainly absurd that it could not possibly have been intended by the Legislature.Â  Section 38-77-160 requires an offer of optional UIM coverage â€œup to the limits of the liability coverage.â€Â  If an automobile insurer providing only collision insurance to its insured falls within the UIM requirements of Section 38-77-160, then arguably under the statute, it must provide liability coverage up to the amount provided by another insurer despite the fact the collision insurer never contracted to provide liability insurance.Â  If interpreted broadly, it would also require an insurer providing only collision insurance to the insured to make a meaningful offer of UIM to an insured who previously bought liability insurance from another carrier.Â  This would be a far-reaching conclusion, which would require a subsequent insurer providing only collision insurance to determine what, if any, liability insurance the insured may have with another carrier.Â  We do not believe the Legislature intended an insurer providing only collision coverage be subject to potential liability in amounts under a contract to which it was not a party.
Second, Davis provides limited guidance in this case.Â  The only issue before the Court of Appeals was whether the State Insurance Reserve Fund, a unique entity, was an â€œautomobile insurance carrier.â€Â  It is undisputed in this case that Occidental is an automobile insurance carrier. The conclusion in Davis is inapposite under the facts of this case.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, we conclude the â€œmeaningful offerâ€ provision under Â§ 38-77-160 is triggered only when an insurer offers liability insurance and does not require an insurer providing only collision coverage to make an offer of UIM.Â  Accordingly, we answer the first certified question: no.Â  Our disposition of this issue makes it unnecessary to address the second certified question.Â  
CERTIFIED QUESTIONS ANSWERED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

Â [1] The Court of Appeals concluded the State Insurance Reserve Fund is a special fund established and administered by the State Budget and Control Board under direct authority from the General Assembly and is thus not a corporation, fraternal organization, partnership, etc.Â  Davis, 298 S.C. at 138, 378 S.E.2d at 606.

The Supreme Court of South Carolina
RE: Amendments to the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure

ORDER

By order dated January 26, 2005 (attached), certain amendments 
  to the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure were submitted to the General 
  Assembly pursuant to Art. V, § 4A, of the South Carolina Constitution. 
  Since ninety days have passed since submission without rejection by the 
General Assembly, these amendments are effective immediately.
 IT IS SO ORDERED.

  
    
    
      s/Jean H. Toal                                    C.J.
              
              s/James E. Moore                             J.
              
              s/John H. Waller, Jr.                           J.
      s/E.C. Burnett, III                                 J.
      s/Costa M. Pleicones                        J.
    
  

Columbia, South Carolina
April 27, 2005


The Supreme Court of South Carolina

ORDER

Pursuant to Art. V, §4 of the South Carolina Constitution, the 
  South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure are amended as provided in the 
  attachment to this order. These amendments shall be submitted to the 
  General Assembly as provided by Art. V, § 4A of the South Carolina 
Constitution.
 IT IS SO ORDERED.

  
    
    
      s/Jean H. Toal                                    C.J.
              
              s/James E. Moore                             J.
              
              s/John H. Waller, Jr.                           J.
      s/E.C. Burnett, III                                 J.
      s/Costa M. Pleicones                        J.
    
  

Columbia, South Carolina
January 26, 2005

AMENDMENTS TO THE SOUTH CAROLINA
RULES OF CIVIL PROCEDURE
 (1) Rule 5(a) is amended to read as follows:

    (a) Service: When Required. Unless otherwise ordered by the court 
    because of numerous defendants or other reasons, all (1) written orders; 
    (2) pleadings subsequent to the original summons and complaint, which 
    includes answers, counterclaims, cross claims, replies and amended 
    complaints; (3) written motions, other than ones which may be heard ex 
    parte; (4) written notices; (5) discovery requests and responses; (6) 
    appearances; (7) demands; (8) offers of judgment; (9) designations of 
    record or case; (10) grounds or exceptions on appeal; and (11) other 
    similar papers shall be served upon each of the parties of record. No 
    service need be made on parties in default for failure to appear, except 
    that pleadings asserting new or additional claims for relief against them 
    shall be served upon them in the manner provided for serving of 
    summons in Rule 4, and notice of any trial or hearing on unliquidated 
  damages shall also be given to parties in default.

  (2) The following is added to the end of Rule 5(a): 
 
 Note to 2005 Amendment: 


   This amendment to subsection (a) makes explicit that all major 
    documents and papers, including, but not limited to, pleadings and 
    amended pleadings, discovery requests and responses, motions and 
    similar papers are to be served on every party of record. The 
    amendment also adds the word “grounds” in subsection (a)(10). 
	 

  (3) The first paragraph of Rule 30(a)(2) is amended to read as follows:

    (2) Limitations. A witness may be compelled to attend in the county 
    in which he resides or is employed or transacts his business in person, 
    or at such other convenient place as is fixed by an order of the court. A 
    party may be compelled to attend in the county in which the subject 
    civil action is pending, or in the county in which he resides or is employed or transacts business, or at such other convenient place as is fixed by an order of the court.

  (4) The following is added to the end of Rule 30(a)(2):
 Note to 2005 Amendment:

   Rule 30(a)(2) previously established the counties in which a witness, 
    but not a party, could be deposed. The rule is amended to add that a 
    party may be deposed in the county where the action is pending, as well as where the deponent resides, or is employed or transacts business in person, or where set by order of the court.

RE: Amendments to Rule 227, SCACR

ORDER

Pursuant to Article V, § 4, of the South Carolina Constitution,   Rule 227 of the South Carolina Appellate Court Rules is amended as set forth in   the attachment to this order. These amendments shall be submitted to the General   Assembly as provided by Article V, § 4A, of the South Carolina Constitution. 
 
IT IS SO ORDERED.  

  
    
    
      s/Jean H. Toal                                    C.J.
              
              s/James E. Moore                             J.
              
              s/John H. Waller, Jr.                           J.
      s/E.C. Burnett, III                                 J.
      s/Costa M. Pleicones                        J.
    
  

Columbia , South CarolinaJanuary 31, 2005

AMENDMENTS TO RULE 227 OF THE SOUTH CAROLINA
	APPELLATE COURT   RULES 

(1) Sections (c) through (j) of Rule 227, SCACR, are re-lettered   as Sections (d) through (k).
(2) Section (c) is added to Rule 227, SCACR, to read as   follows:

  (c) Explanation Required. If the lower court   has determined that the post-conviction relief action is barred as successive or   being untimely under the statute of limitations, the petitioner must, at the   time the notice of appeal is filed, provide an explanation as to why this   determination was improper. This explanation must contain sufficient facts,   argument and citation to legal authority to show that there is an arguable basis   for asserting that the determination by the lower court was improper. If the   petitioner fails to make a sufficient showing, the notice of appeal may be   dismissed.

(3) Rule 227, SCACR, is amended by adding the following:

  (l) Transfer of Cases to the Court of Appeals. The Supreme Court may transfer a case filed under this rule to the Court of   Appeals. If transferred, the Court of Appeals shall proceed with the case in the   same manner as the Supreme Court would have done under this rule with the   exception that a petition for a writ of certiorari may be granted by one judge   of a three-judge panel. Review of any final decision of the Court of Appeals   shall be by a petition for a writ of certiorari under Rule 226, SCACR.

IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
In the Matter of John B. Bowden,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 25978
Submitted March 25, 2005 - Filed May 9, 2005

PUBLIC REPRIMAND


  
    
      
Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Barbara M. Seymour, Senior Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
John P. Freeman, of Columbia, for respondent.
      
    
  


 PER CURIAM:Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) and respondent have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits misconduct and agrees to the issuance of a letter of caution, admonition, or a public reprimand.Â  We accept the agreement and issue a public reprimand.Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.
FACTS
Respondent was hired as an associate to manage the Greenville office of the Forquer Law Firm.Â  Respondent worked under the supervision of Robert Forquer who is not licensed in South Carolina and who works in the firmâ€™s Charlotte, North Carolina, office.Â  When respondent learned it was the firmâ€™s practice to inflate government recording fees on HUD-1settlement statements, he questioned Mr. Forquer about the practice.Â  Mr. Forquer assured respondent that the practice was ethical and legal.Â  
Respondent has been informed by ODC that the Forquer Law Firm failed to maintain sufficient records of the recording fee charges and failed to identify and track client funds relating thereto in its accounts.Â  No record of the actual amounts paid for recording fees were kept in the closing files and no accounting of the overcharges was made to clients.Â  The funds obtained in excess of the actual recording fees were used for a variety of purposes including office expenses, correction of errors in closings, payroll or other payments to staff, and payments in various amounts to Mr. Forquer and a former partner, Mr. Green.Â  
While respondent had signatory authority on the firmâ€™s bank accounts, he had no access to or responsibility for its financial records.Â  Respondent knew that the management and recordkeeping of the firmâ€™s accounts was handled by Mr. Forquer in the firmâ€™s Charlotte office.Â  Respondent was unaware that the firm was not complying with the requirements of Rule 417, SCACR, or that Mr. Forquer was using the excess recording fees for firm and personal expenses.Â  Respondent did not profit in any way from the overcharges.Â  
Respondent acknowledges that it was his responsibility 1) to inform his clients they were being charged more than the actual cost of the recording fees and 2) to ensure the accuracy of information contained in the HUD-1 forms in the closings he supervised.Â  Respondent further acknowledges his ethical duty to ensure the firmâ€™s compliance with his obligation of safekeeping of funds and financial recordkeeping, particularly when those responsibilities were handled by non-lawyers or lawyers not licensed in South Carolina.Â  Respondent acknowledges that, as office manager and supervisor of associates, he had additional responsibilities to ensure his staffâ€™s compliance with the Rules of Professional Conduct.Â  
Respondent has fully cooperated with ODCâ€™s investigation. 
LAW
Respondent admits that, by his misconduct, he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.15 (addressing lawyerâ€™s responsibility for safekeeping client funds); Rule 5.1 (lawyer shall be responsible for another lawyerâ€™s violation of the Rules of Professional Conduct if, with knowledge of the specific conduct, the lawyer ratifies the conduct involved); Rule 5.2 (lawyer is bound by the Rules of Professional Conduct notwithstanding lawyer acts at the direction of another person); and Rule 8.3 (lawyer having knowledge that another lawyer has committed a violation of the Rules of Professional Conduct that raises a substantial question as that lawyerâ€™s honesty, integrity, trustworthiness, or fitness as a lawyer in other respects shall inform the appropriate professional authority).Â  In addition, respondent admits he failed to comply with Rule 417, SCACR (addressing financial recordkeeping).Â  Respondent acknowledges that his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
We find that respondentâ€™s misconduct warrants a public reprimand.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and publicly reprimand respondent for his misconduct.
 PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
John Gadson and Julia Gadson as personal representatives of the Estate of James
Gadson, et al.,        Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
J. Gregory Hembree as successor in interest to Ralph Wilson, Solicitor for the Fifteenth Judicial Circuit, ex officio on behalf of the Georgetown County Sheriff's Office and the Georgetown Police Department,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
John L. Breeden, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25980
Heard March 16, 2005 - Filed May 9, 2005

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
Michael S. Church, of Turner, Padget, Graham & Laney, P.A., and Larry C. Smith, both of Columbia, for Appellants.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Deputy Attorney General T. Stephen Lynch, Assistant Deputy Attorney General J. Emory Smith, Jr., all of Columbia, and Lisa Marie Hatley, of Conway, for Respondents.
      
    
  

JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  This is an action seeking return of property pursuant to the innocent owner provision of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-586 (2002).Â  The trial court granted Respondentsâ€™ motion for dismissal and summary judgment.Â  This Court certified the case from the Court of Appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  We affirm as modified.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
James Gadson owned a lot and building in the City of Georgetown.Â  He leased the building to Harriet Ann Singleton Evans.Â  Evans operated the Winyah Grill, a bar and lounge, on the premises.[1]Â  Ronald Lee McCants, an employee of Evans was arrested for distribution of crack cocaine inside Gadsonâ€™s building.[2]
On May 4, 1993, Judge Shuler signed a seizure warrant authorizing the solicitor, on behalf of the Georgetown County Sheriffâ€™s Office and Georgetown City Police Department, to seize the property due to violations of the drug code.Â  Judge Shuler also signed a notice of seizure on May 4, 1993.Â  
On May 13, 1993, the State Law Enforcement Division (SLED) inspected the building and found numerous structural and electrical defects and also determined the fire exits were wholly inadequate.Â  On May 17, 1993, the Resident Fire Marshal and Mayor of Georgetown signed a â€œnotice of unsafe building.â€ The notice provided that if remedial work was not completed by June 30, 1993, to correct the building, structural, and fire code deficiencies, the City of Georgetown would demolish the property.
Also on May 17, 1993, the special prosecutor filed a lis pendens giving notice of the forfeiture action based on the controlled substances violations.Â  City Council revoked Evansâ€™ business license on May 24, 1993, due to the controlled substances sales, as well as, building and fire code violations.Â  
In July 1993, the City of Georgetown demolished the building after Gadson failed to take corrective actions to resolve the building defects.Â  On November 2, 1993, the City filed a demolition lien on the property in the amount of $16,292.50.Â  
By motion dated April 28, 1994, Gadson requested the circuit court â€œrestoreâ€ the property to him pursuant to the innocent owner provision of the forfeiture statute.Â  See 44-53-586(b)(1) (2002).Â  On May 20, 1994, Judge Sydney Floyd denied Gadson relief on his motions.
On December 7, 1994, Gadson filed a suit in federal court.Â  On May 3, 1996, Judge Norton signed an order effecting the partiesâ€™ agreement to voluntarily dismiss the federal suit.Â  The parties agreed Gadson could re-file the federal action prior to the close of the 1996 calendar year.Â  Gadson failed to re-file the federal lawsuit by December 31, 1996.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In late 1996, Gadson died.Â  On June 20, 1997, the probate court appointed the personal representatives of Gadsonâ€™s estate.Â  On January 28, 1998, Gadsonâ€™s estate filed a complaint seeking a declaratory judgment dissolving the seizure warrant and lien.Â  On May 5, 1999, the circuit court dismissed the complaint because there was a prior pending action (this action) which provided Gadsonâ€™s estate the exclusive remedy.Â  The order allowed Gadsonâ€™s estate to proceed with the April 1994 state court lawsuit.Â  
On October 21, 2003, Appellants filed a motion for summary judgment requesting the seizure warrant and lis pendens placed on the property be dissolved and vacated.Â  Appellants also allege they are entitled to the return of property still in possession of the Respondents, and recovery of the value of property demolished.Â  The circuit court granted the Respondentsâ€™ motion for dismissal and summary judgment, concluding (1) Appellants failed to state a claim against the solicitor; (2) there is no genuine issue of material fact regarding Appellantsâ€™ entitlement to damages under the forfeiture statute; and (3) Appellants have failed to state a claim for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  This appeal followed.
ISSUE

Did the circuit court err in granting Respondentsâ€™ motion for summary judgment?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
Summary judgment is appropriate when it is clear that there is no genuine issue of material fact and that the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  CafÃ© Assocs., Ltd. v. Gerngross, 305 S.C. 6, 406 S.E.2d 162 (1991).Â  Summary judgment is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law.Â  Middleborough Horizontal Property Regime Council of Co-Owners v. Montedison, 320 S.C. 470, 465 S.E.2d 765 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  Further, summary judgment should not be granted even when there is no dispute as to the evidentiary facts, if there is a dispute as to the conclusion to be drawn therefrom.Â  MacFarlane v. Manly, 274 S.C. 392, 264 S.E.2d 838 (1980).Â  An appellate court reviews the granting of summary judgment under the same standard applied by the trial court.Â  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 548 S.E.2d 868 (2001).Â Â Â Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants argue the Georgetown City Police Department and the Georgetown County Sheriffâ€™s Office, acting through the Solicitor for the Fifteenth Judicial Circuit (hereinafter referred to as the â€œseizing agencyâ€), had a duty to maintain the seized property after Judge Shuler signed the seizure warrant on May 4, 1993, authorizing the solicitor to seize the property due to controlled substances violations.Â  Therefore, according to Appellants, the seizing agency violated its duty to take reasonable steps to maintain the property when the City of Georgetown demolished the property. Furthermore, Appellants contend they could not be expected to defend against the demolition of the property because the seizing agency exercised control over the property once the seizure warrant was issued.
Initially, we agree with Appellants that a seizing agency has a duty to take reasonable steps to maintain property once a warrant is issued for seizure of the property.Â  Section 44-53-520(i) (2002) provides:

Law enforcement agencies seizing propertyÂ  [that is subject toÂ  forfeiture under this section] shall take reasonable steps to maintain the property.Â  Equipment and conveyances seized must be removed to an appropriate place for storage.Â  Any monies seized must be deposited in an interest bearing account pending final disposition by the court unless the seizing agency determines the monies to be of an evidential nature and provides for security in another manner. 

(emphasis added).Â  
The plain language of Section 44-53-520(i) unequivocally provides that agencies seizing property have an obligation to take reasonable steps to maintain the property.Â  The circuit court held the duty to take reasonable steps to maintain the property did not arise in this case because a forfeiture action was never initiated under Section 44-53-530(a) (2002).Â  We disagree.
S.C. Code Ann. 44-53-530(a) provides that forfeiture of the property is â€œaccomplished by petition of the Attorney General or his designee or the circuit solicitor or his designee to the court of common pleas for the jurisdiction where the items were seized.â€Â  However, a seizing agency may seize property until lawful disposition of the property is ordered and the property is declared forfeited by petition.Â  Section 44-53-520(b) provides, in part, that property subject to forfeiture may be seized by the department having authority upon warrant issued by any court having jurisdiction over the property.Â  Such warrant was issued in this case.Â  A forfeiture action, however, was never initiated under Section 44-53-530(a).
The seizing agencyâ€™s duty to take reasonable steps to maintain the property arises upon seizure pursuant to Section 44-53-520(b) and before forfeiture of the property is formally accomplished by petition pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-530(a).
Although, the seizing agency has a duty to take reasonable steps to maintain the property upon issuance of a seizure warrant, the seizing agency in this case did not violate its duty under the facts of this case.Â  We decline to impose a duty on a seizing agency to commence legal action in an effort to protect property subject to a seizure warrant against a wholly independent legal process initiated by the City of Georgetown.Â  The Georgetown City Police Department and the Georgetown County Sheriffâ€™s Office, acting through the Solicitor for the Fifteenth Judicial Circuit, as the lawful seizing agency, did not violate the duty to take reasonable steps to maintain the property because the City of Georgetown acted under lawful process in condemning the property based on independent violations of existing building and fire code standards.Â  Forfeiture and condemnation proceedings are competing legal processes and, as such, the seizing agency acting pursuant to its forfeiture authority has no duty to defend against cityâ€™s process.Â  
Recognizing that legal actions of forfeiture and condemnation are distinct, we conclude any defenses Appellants may have asserted were against the City of Georgetown for the condemnation of the building.Â  Therefore, the circuit court properly granted Respondentsâ€™ motion for summary judgment because there is no genuine issue of material fact the seizing agency violated its duty to take reasonable steps to maintain the property.Â  Finally, our resolution of this issue is dispositive and we need not address Appellantsâ€™ remaining issues regarding whether the City of Georgetown was an indispensable party in this action, what remedies Appellants would be entitled to under the forfeiture statute, and Appellantsâ€™ request for attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Whiteside v. Cherokee County School Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 428 S.E.2d 886 (1993) (appellate court need not address remaining issue when resolution of prior issue is
dispositive).
 AFFIRMED AS MODIFED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice Marc H. Westbrook, concur.

  [1] The bar is also referred to by other names such as â€œShabazz,â€ â€œThe Elks Club,â€ â€œShabazz Grill,â€ and â€œShabazz Bar and Lounge.â€Â  
  [2] Between December 1992 and February 1993, undercover officers purchased controlled substances on at least twenty-six occasions.Â  Between 1984 and 1993, the Cityâ€™s Police Department has responded to over 180 crime calls at this location.Â

description: Appellant was convicted of grand larceny greater than $5000 and sentenced to ten years. The Court affirmed and held the trial court did not err in admitting a photograph of the appellant at a Halloween party where he was dressed as a prisoner and in refusing to allow the appellant to introduce polygraph results in rebuttal.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Brennan Shay Jackson,        Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Calhoun County
James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25983
Heard March 16, 2005 - Filed May 9, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Jack B. Swerling, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster; Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh; Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott; Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark
Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert D. Robbins, of Summerville, for
Respondent. 
      
    
  


JUSTICE WALLER:  The appellant Brennan Shay Jackson (Jackson) was convicted of grand larceny and sentenced to ten years.Â  He contends the trial court erred in admitting a photograph of him at a Halloween party when he was dressed as a prisoner and in refusing to allow him to introduce polygraph results in rebuttal after an insurance adjuster had testified that he had asked Jackson whether he would be willing to take a polygraph.Â  We affirm.
FACTSÂ  
Jackson is the nephew of Barbara and Bobby Ayer and the owner of a pawnshop.Â  Jackson also cleaned and did odd jobs for the Ayers three days/week. Â Â Â  The State alleged that sometime between June 1 and December 16, 2000, Jackson stole approximately $190,000-200,000 in old collectible coins and bills from the Ayerâ€™s two home safes.Â  There was no sign of forced entry.[1]Â  
Jackson testified Barbara paid him between $500-1,000 per week. Further, he testified Barbara gave him gold and silver coins and old money on many occasions. Barbara, however, testified she paid him only $100 per week and she never paid him with silver dollars or other old money.Â  Over the years, Barbara had given Jackson large sums of money to help him purchase a car, a truck, and a cruise for Jacksonâ€™s father, and open the pawnshop. [2] Â  
Upon discovering that the coins and money were missing, Bobby called his insurance agent.Â  Insurance adjuster Bill Spell investigated the theft.Â  During his investigation, Spell interviewed Jackson and Stephen Phillips who had worked for the Ayers during the fall of 2000.Â  At trial, Jackson admitted he sold some old paper money and coins worth several hundred dollars to John â€œSmokeyâ€ Dukes, Phillipsâ€™ cousin, at a Halloween party.Â  In fact, Jackson admitted some of the money that was sold to Smokey Dukes came from the Ayerâ€™s house.Â  However, he testified his aunt had given him the money.Â  Jackson also admitted he sold approximately $8,000 worth of Krugerrands to Carolina Gold and Silver and Baxleyâ€™s Pawnshop. At trial, Phillips testified about Jacksonâ€™s various cash expenditures between June and December 2000. He specifically testified Jackson spent $800 to hire a band to play at the farmerâ€™s market for a football game; bought some guns; and paid $2,000 in labor costs for Phillips to build him a dog kennel. He also testified Jackson bought a $13,000 boat in March 2000.Â  Additionally, there was testimony Jackson paid $4,000 cash for a cruise in the fall of 2000.Â Â Â  
ISSUES   

1)    Did the trial court err in admitting photographs
of Jackson in a prisonerâ€™s costume at a Halloween
party? 
2)    Did the trial court err in denying Jacksonâ€™s
request to introduce evidence that he had passed a polygraph test? 

DISCUSSION

1)Â  Photograph

During a pre-trial hearing, Jackson objected to the Stateâ€™s introduction of several photographs taken of appellant at a Halloween party held in 2000.[3]Â  Appellant was dressed as a prisoner.Â  The State later sought to introduce only one of the photographs to show appellant was at the party along with twoÂ  Stateâ€™s witnesses who would testify that Jackson had sold them things stolen from the victims.Â  Jackson contended the photograph was prejudicial because he was dressed in a prison uniform.Â  He argued the photograph was more prejudicial than probative.Â  
On appeal, Jackson contends the photograph gave the impression that he had a light-hearted attitude toward lawlessness and found criminal behavior amusing.Â  Jackson contends the photograph was irrelevant to any issue.Â  Further, he argues he never contested he was at the Halloween party and offered to stipulate he was there. 
The State, however, has the right to prove every element of the crime charged and is not obligated to rely upon a defendant's stipulation. State v. Johnson, 338 S.C. 114, 122, 525 S.E.2d 519, 523 (2000).Â  The relevancy, materiality, and admissibility of photographs are matters left to the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  State v. Kornahrens, 290 S.C. 281, 350 S.E.2d 180 (1986).Â Â  â€œ[T]here is no abuse of discretion if the offered photograph serves to corroborate testimony.â€Â  Johnson, 338 S.C. at 122, 525 S.E.2d at 523.Â Â Â  However, photographs calculated to arouse the sympathy or prejudice of the jury should be excluded if they are irrelevant or not necessary to substantiate material facts or conditions. State v. Brazell, 325 S.C. 65, 480 S.E.2d 64 (1997).Â  To constitute unfair prejudice, the photographs must create â€œan undue tendency to suggest a decision on an improper basis, commonly, though not necessarily, an emotional one."Â  State v. Alexander, 303 S.C. 377, 382, 401 S.E.2d 146, 149 (1991).Â  Even if evidence was irrelevant and thus wrongly admitted by the trial judge, its admission may constitute harmless error if the irrelevant evidence did not affect the outcome of the trial. State v. Johnson, 306 S.C. 119, 410 S.E.2d 547 (1991).
The State contends it introduced the photograph to show Jackson was at the party and had sold stolen items.Â  While the photograph does not show any of the stolen items, Jackson testified that in the photograph he was selling some of the alleged stolen goods to Smokey Dukes.Â  Thus, the photograph was clearly relevant.
Further, the photo would not cause the jury to reach a decision on an improper basis.Â  The photo was taken prior to Jackson being identified as a potential suspect and, in fact, prior to the discovery of the crime.Â Â  We find any prejudice from Jackson having on a prisonerâ€™s costume is outweighed by the photographâ€™s probative value.Â  Accordingly, we do not think that the admission of this particular photograph is reversible error.Â  

2) Polygraph test results

Jackson contends the trial court erred in denying his motion to introduce evidence that he had passed a polygraph test given by a private polygrapher.Â Â  Jackson contends the State opened the door and that he should have been allowed to reply.Â Â  During the trial, the State presented a recording of a conversation that the insurance investigator Spell had taped with Jackson.[4]Â Â  During this conversation, Spell asked Jackson whether he would be willing to take a polygraph. [5] Â Â  Jackson answered he would be willing to take a polygraph.Â  Jackson did not make any contemporaneous objection to the reference to a polygraph test.Â  In fact, when the tape of the conversation was initially played, the trial court specifically asked Jackson if he had any objection to the tape being played and he stated no.Â Â  Immediately after the tape was played, the State moved into evidence and Jackson again stated he had â€œ[n]o objection at all.â€Â  
Jackson then informed the trial court that he had a matter he wanted to take up with the court.Â  Jackson stated that the State had opened the door for the admission of polygraph results.[6]Â  The Solicitor responded that he did not believe the door had been opened and further he pointed out that the Sheriff had offered Jackson a polygraph to be administered by State Law Enforcement Division (SLED) but Jackson never took up his offer.Â Â  The trial court told Jackson he would have to hold a Council[7] hearing to determine if the polygraph results were admissible.
Jackson told the trial court he had not prepared for a Council hearing and after some discussion stated he would think about it overnight.Â  The Solicitor reiterated that if Jackson presented any evidence ofÂ  polygraph test results, the State â€œintend[ed]Â  to call the Sheriff to say he was prepared to take [Jackson] to S.L.E.D. and [Jackson] did not take him up on it.â€Â  The next morning trial counsel stated he had thought about it and decided that he would simply ask the witness whether Jackson had agreed to take a polygraph and whether one was administered and â€œleave it at that.â€ Clearly, Jackson abandoned his motion to admit the polygraph test results. [8] Â  
On appeal, Jackson contends that â€œwhile any potential Council issue was waived, the issue of rebuttal was clearly raised and ruled upon by the trial court.â€Â Â  Jackson contends the State â€œopened the door . . . for evidence that [Jackson] took [a polygraph test] and passed itâ€ and he should have been allowed to introduce polygraph evidence in rebuttal.Â  
When a party introduces evidence about a particular matter, the other party is entitled to explain it or rebut it, even if the latter evidence would have been incompetent or irrelevant had it been offered initially. See State v. Foster, 354 S.C. 614, 582 S.E.2d 426 (2003).Â  However, here, Jackson waived any argument he had when he acquiesced the next morning and stated he would ask Spell if he had administered a polygraph and â€œleave it at that.â€Â Â  Jackson did not note any objection.Â  Jackson made a decision to not introduce any evidence of the polygraph test results in rebuttal.Â  Accordingly, this issue is not preserved.
In any event, Jackson was not prejudiced. State v. Locklair, 341 S.C. 352, 535 S.E.2d 420 (2000) (holding error without prejudice does not warrant reversal).Â  The testimony before the jury was that Jackson stated he would be willing to take a polygraph and Spell testified he never offered him one.Â Â  This would not leave the jury with the impression that Jackson had taken and failed a polygraph.Â  Accordingly, based on the foregoing, Jacksonâ€™s conviction and sentence areÂ  
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., BURNETT, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice Marc H. Westbrook, concur.

[1]Two rings initially thought to also have been stolen were later discovered in the Ayerâ€™s home. 
[2] Barbara had made a deathbed promise to her mother (Jacksonâ€™s grandmother) to take care of Jackson and by all accounts had been extremely generous to Jackson over the years. 
[3]When the State introduced the photograph during trial, Jackson asked the trial court to note his pre-trial objection to its admission.Â  The State argues that Jackson failed to state his objection in terms of Rule 403, SCRE, and therefore is barred from arguing this rule on appeal.Â  While Jackson did not argue specifically Rule 403, he clearly argued that the prejudicial value of the photo outweighed any probative value.Â  Accordingly, Jackson properly preserved this objection.
[4]We note trial counsel was present at this meeting.Â  
[5]The pertinent part of the conversation is as follows:
Spell:Â  Would you be willing to take a polygraph?
Appellant:Â  Yeah.Â  Thatâ€™d be fine.
Spell: Okay. You donâ€™tÂ  have any problem doing that?
Appellant:Â  Unhuh.Â  Thatâ€™s fine.
[6]Apparently, prior to trial Jackson had taken a private polygraph and passed.Â  However, neither the results ofÂ  this polygraph nor the questions asked during the test were proffered for the record.
[7]State v. Council, 335 S.C. 1, 515 S.E.2d 508 (1999)(holding the admissibility of polygraph tests must be analyzed under Rules 702 and 403, SCRE.). 
[8]Spell later testified that he asked Jackson if he would be willing to take a polygraph and his response was â€œsureâ€ but he never offered Jackson one.

title: In the Matter fo Hattie E. Boyce
description: This a disciplinary opinion in which the Court publicly reprimands an attorney.
text:
IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA



IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter of Hattie
        E. Boyce,       
        Respondent. 
      
    
  


Opinion No. 25985
Submitted April 26, 2005 - Filed May 23, 2005

PUBLIC REPRIMAND


  
    
      
Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Joseph P. Turner, Jr., Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
Hattie E. Boyce, of Spartanburg, pro se.Â  
      
    
  


 PER CURIAM:Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) and respondent have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits misconduct and agrees to either an admonition or a public reprimand.Â  We accept the agreement and issue a public reprimand.Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as
follows.
FACTS
On or about July 9, 2004, respondent was the closing attorney in a real estate transaction.Â  Respondent represented Borrower.Â  Borrower and his wife had obtained approval for an equity credit line loan from Wells Fargo; the loan was to be secured by Borrowerâ€™s residence.Â  Borrower had contacted respondent and requested she assist in a â€œwitness onlyâ€ closing of the line of credit from Wells Fargo.Â Â  
Respondent did not prepare a deed, mortgage, note, or other legal instrument related to the closing of the real estate transaction; she did not ensure that another attorney did so.Â  Neither respondent nor someone under her supervision conducted a title examination or prepared abstracts; respondent did not ensure another attorney or someone under another attorneyâ€™s supervision did so.Â  Neither respondent nor someone under her supervision recorded documents at the Register of Deeds; respondent did not ensure that another attorney or someone under another attorneyâ€™s supervision did so.Â  
Respondent signed the HUD-1 statement certifying thereon that she had prepared the statement, that it was a true and accurate account of the transaction, and that she had or would cause funds or be disbursed in accordance with the statement.Â  Despite signing the HUD-1 statement that she had or would disburse the funds, respondent acknowledges she did not do so.Â  
Despite certifying on the HUD-1 statement that her fee was $100.00 and that the HUD-1 statement was a true and accurate account of the transaction, respondent sought to collect $150.00.Â  The $150.00 fee had been set by respondentâ€™s secretary.Â Â Â  
Borrower told respondent that the attorneyâ€™s fee was to be paid by Wells Fargo.Â  When Wells Fargo did not pay the $150.00 fee, respondent faxed a letter to Borrower and to Borrowerâ€™s employer at their place of business.Â  The letter threatened to sue both Borrower individually and the employerâ€™s business and to send a copy of the lawsuit to both the Attorney General and the Better Business Bureau so as to gain an advantage in the collection of her civil debt.Â  Respondentâ€™s letter threatened treble damages even though she would not be entitled to treble damages under South Carolina law.Â  
Neither Borrowerâ€™s employer nor the employerâ€™s business were a party to the loan.Â  Neither Borrowerâ€™s employer nor his business were clients of respondent.Â  Despite this fact, respondent revealed information relating to her representation of Borrower to his employer without Borrowerâ€™s consent.Â  
Respondent states she was under the mistaken impression that Borrowerâ€™s place of employment was a party to the loan.Â  Respondentâ€™s fee of $150.00 was ultimately paid by Wells Fargo Bank.Â  
Respondent represents her practice is primarily devoted to family law.Â  She submits this is the only real estate closing she has conducted in her thirteen years of practice and that she was unaware of the requirements imposed upon attorneys in the closing of real estate transactions.Â  Respondent further submits she did not fully understand the concept of treble damages.Â Â Â Â  
After discussing this matter and previous Court decisions with ODC, respondent now recognizes that participating in â€œwitness onlyâ€ closings when no other South Carolina licensed attorney is involved has the effect of assisting in the unauthorized practice of law and constitutes a failure to carry out the responsibilities of a closing attorney as provided by previous directives of this Court.Â  She further recognizes she did not provide her client with competent representation.Â  Respondent agrees that her actions constitute misconduct under the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407,
SCACR.  
Respondent now recognizes that by signing the HUD-1 settlement statement, she represented that a licensed attorney had disbursed the funds and completed the other steps required of a closing attorney by published directives of the Court when in fact she did not do so.Â  Respondent acknowledges this was misconduct.Â  Respondent further recognizes that the threat of criminal prosecution and collection of civil damages not available under the circumstances constitutes misconduct.Â  
Respondent states her misconduct was unintentional.Â  She represents that, in the future, she will make every effort not to handle matters without first making herself familiar with the applicable guidelines and law.Â  
Respondent has no prior disciplinary history and submits that her conduct in this matter was uncharacteristic.Â  ODC asserts respondent has been very cooperative and forthright during the course of its investigation.Â  
LAW
Respondent admits that by her misconduct she has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation to a client); Rule 1.6 (lawyer shall not reveal information relating to representation of a client unless client consents after consultation); Rule 4.5 (lawyer shall not threaten to present criminal charges solely to obtain an advantage in a civil matter); Rule 5.5(b) (lawyer shall not assist a person who is not a member of the bar in the performance of activity that constitutes the unauthorized practice of law); Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to violate the Rules of Processional Conduct); Rule 8.4(d) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation); and Rule 8.4(e) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to engage in conduct that is prejudicial to the administration of justice).Â  Respondent acknowledges her misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct) and Rule 7(a)(5) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to engage in conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice or to bring the legal profession into disrepute).Â Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
We find that respondentâ€™s misconduct warrants a public reprimand.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and publicly reprimand respondent for her misconduct.
 PUBLIC REPRIMAND.Â Â Â  
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Owners Insurance Company, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Janette Clayton, Richard Johnston, Jr. a/k/a A. R. Johnston, Jr., Lands Inn, Inc., d/b/a Lands Inn and Comfort Inn, Johnston Company, Inc., Robert Bowen, a/k/a Robert
Bowners, Linda Silver-Jones, R. C. McEntire, Jr., and Carol Stanley, Defendants, of whom Janette Clayton, Lands Inn, Inc. d/b/a Lands Inn and Comfort Inn are, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25986
Heard April 20, 2005 - Filed May 23, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Charles R. Norris, John S. Slosson, and Robert W. Whelan, all of Nelson Mullins Riley & Scarborough, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Ervin Lindsay Blanks, of North Charleston, F. Barron Grier, III, of Grier Law Firm, LLC, of West Columbia, James Edward Bell, III, of Sumter, and John E. Parker, of Peters, Murdaugh, Parker, Eltzroth & Detrick, PA, of Hampton, for Respondents.
      
    
  


JUSTICE PLEICONES: Â This is an appeal from a circuit court order granting respondent Lands Inn and respondent Clayton summary judgment on an insurance policy coverage question, and holding Lands Inn was entitled to indemnification by appellant (Owners) for a $1.25 million judgment in Claytonâ€™s tort suit.Â  Owners asserts the circuit court erred in finding that coverage was not precluded by the policyâ€™s employment-related practices (ERP) exclusion, and that several other statements in the order are incorrect.Â  We hold that the ERP exclusion does not apply, and that the inaccuracies in the order have not prejudiced Owners.Â  We therefore affirm.
FACTS
The underlying tort judgment was obtained by Clayton, a former manager of Lands Inn, a motel.Â  Lands Inn fired Clayton for allegedly stealing and embezzling funds.Â  After she was fired, two individuals who called the motel and asked to speak to Clayton were told by a Lands Inn employee that she had been terminated because she had stolen money or misappropriated funds.Â  After a criminal charge against Clayton was nol prossed, she filed a civil suit against Lands Inn.Â  The case was submitted to the jury on three causes of action: malicious prosecution, slander, and negligence.Â  The jury returned a general verdict ofÂ  $1.25 million, of which $500,000 was for compensatory damages and $750,000 for punitive damages.
Owners provided Commercial General Liability (CGL) coverage to Lands Inn.Â  It defended the Clayton suit under a full reservation of rights, but prior to that trial commenced this declaratory judgment suit.Â  Owners now appeals a circuit court order granting Lands Inn summary judgment on the coverage issue and holding Lands Inn entitled to indemnification for the $1.25 million Clayton verdict.[1]  
ISSUES
On appeal, Owners raises these issues:

  
    1)
    
    Did the trial judge err in finding the policy language ambiguous?
    
  
  
    2)
    
    Did the trial court err in holding the ERP exclusion did not apply?
    
  
  
    3)
     
    Did the trial court err in holding that Owners must indemnify Lands Inn for $1.25 million when the policy limit is $1 million?
    
  
  
    4)
    
    Did the trial court’s order and judgment form contain other inaccuracies?
    
  

A.Â  Ambiguous Policy
The trial court found the CGL policy â€œpotentiallyâ€ ambiguous since it purported first to cover malicious prosecution and slander, but then to exclude slander in the ERP exclusion.Â  Relying on S.C. State Budget & Control Bd. v. Prince, 304 S.C. 241, 403 S.E.2d 643 (1991), the circuit court concluded that such an inclusion/exclusion situation creates an ambiguity. Â Owners argues that, logically, exclusions can only apply to otherwise covered items, for if the item is not covered it is by definition excluded.Â  We agree with Owners that the trial court misread Prince. 
The policy provides this coverage:

COVERAGE A. BODILY INJURY AND PROPERTY 
DAMAGE LIABILITY
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Insuring Agreement.
We will pay those sums that the insured becomes legally obligated to pay as damages because of â€œbodily injuryâ€ or â€œproperty damageâ€ to which this insurance applies.
COVERAGE B. PERSONAL AND ADVERTISING
INJURY LIABILITY 
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Insuring Agreement
We will pay those sums that the insured becomes legally obligated to pay as damages because of â€œpersonal injuryâ€ to which this coverage part applies.

The Definitions section of the policy then provides:

3.Â Â Â Â Â Â  â€œBodily injuryâ€ means bodily injury, sickness or disease sustained by a person, including death resulting from any of these at any one time.
10.Â Â Â Â  â€œPersonal injuryâ€ means, other than â€œbodily injuryâ€, arising out of one or more of the following offenses:

  
    a.
    False arrest, detention or imprisonment;
  
  
    b.
    Malicious prosecution;
  
  
    c.
    The wrongful eviction from, wrongful entry into, or invasion of the right of private occupancy of a room, dwelling or premises that a person occupies by or on behalf of its owner, landlord or lessor;
  
  
    d.
    Oral or written publication of material that slanders or libels a person or organization or disparages a person’s or organization’s goods, products or services; or
  
  
    e.
    Oral or written publication of material that violates a person’s right of privacy.
  


(emphasis supplied).
The purported Â â€œambiguityâ€ arises because the ERP exclusion provides:
EMPLOYMENT-RELATED PRACTICES EXCLUSION

  
    
      1. 
      The following exclusion is added to COVERAGE A (Section I): 
    
    
       
      o.
      “Bodily injury” arising out of any:
    
    
       
       
      (1) 
      Refusal to employ;
    
    
       
       
      (2)
      Termination of employment;
    
    
       
       
      (3)
      Coercion, demotion, evaluation, reassignment, discipline, defamation, harassment, humiliation, discrimination or other employment-related practices, policies, acts, or omissions; or
    
    
       
       
      (4) 
      Consequential “bodily injury” as a result of (1) through (3) above.
    
    
       
       
       
       
    
    
       
      This exclusion applies whether the insured may be held liable as an employer or in any other capacity and to any obligation to share damages with or to repay someone else who must pay damages because of the injury.
    
    
       
       
       
       
    
    
      2.
      The following exclusion is added to COVERAGE B (Section I):
    
    
       
      c.
      “Personal injury” arising out of any:
    
    
       
       
      (1)
      Refusal to employ;
    
    
       
       
      (2)
      Termination of employment;
    
    
       
       
      (3)
      Coercion, demotion, evaluation, reassignment, discipline, defamation, harassment, humiliation, discrimination or other employment-related practices, policies, acts, or omissions; or
    
    
       
       
      (4) 
      Consequential “personal injury” as a result of (1) through (3) above.
    
  

(emphasis supplied).
In Prince, the insurance policy defined â€œpersonal injuriesâ€ to include several intentional torts.Â  The policyâ€™s definition of â€œoccurrence,â€ however, required â€œan accidentâ€¦which results in personal injury or property damage neither expected nor intended from the standpoint of the insured.â€Â  The Prince court held that there was an ambiguity in this definitional section, in that the intentional torts defined as â€œpersonal injuriesâ€ were effectively eliminated by the definition of â€œoccurrence.â€Â  We agree with Owners that Prince is inapposite, as here the coverage â€œeliminationâ€ is found in one of the policyâ€™s exclusions, not in inconsistent definitions.
The trial court erred in finding the policy ambiguous.
B.Â  Application of the ERP Exclusion
Insurance policy exclusions are construed most strongly against the insurance company, which also bears the burden of establishing the exclusionâ€™s applicability.Â  Boggs v. Aetna Cas. and Sur. Co., 272 S.C. 460, 252 S.E.2d 565 (1979).Â  In addition, since the Clayton jury returned a general verdict, a finding that any of the three claims submitted to that jury is not excluded answers the coverage question.Â  See, e.g., Frazier v. Badger, 361 S.C. 94, 603 S.E.2d 587 (2004) (where general verdict is supported by at least one theory it will be upheld on appeal).Â  As discussed below, we find that coverage for the Clayton defamation award is not precluded by the ERP exclusion.
The ERP exclusion specifically excludes coverage for â€œBodily Injuryâ€ and â€œPersonal Injuryâ€ â€œarising out of anyâ€¦defamationâ€¦or other employment-related practices, policies, acts, or omissionsâ€¦.â€Â  In South Carolina, the term â€œarising out ofâ€ when used in an insurance policy exclusion should be narrowly construed to mean â€œcaused by.â€Â  McPherson v. Michigan Mut. Ins. Co., 310 S.C. 316, 426 S.E.2d 770 (1993).Â  Further, in determining whether post-termination defamations such as the ones here fall within an ERP exclusion, courts generally inquire whether the statement was made in the context of employment, and whether the statementâ€™s content describes the employeeâ€™s performance.Â  HS Servs. v. Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co., 109 F.3d 642 (9th Cir. 1997) (defamation not clearly employment related because while statementâ€™s contents related to employment, the statements were not made in the context of employment, but rather to competitors to discourage business dealings with former employee); Adams v. Pro Source, 231 F.Supp.2d 499 (M.D. La. 2002); see also Frank and Freedus v. Allstate Ins. Co., 52 Cal. Rptr.2d 678 (Cal. Dist. Ct. App. 1996) (was post-termination statement directed to performance while employed and made in employment context).
In her tort suit, Clayton presented evidence of two separate defamations.Â  One occurred when a former hotel guest called Lands Inn and asked to speak with Clayton.Â  When told she â€œwas no longer here,â€ the caller asked whether she had quit and was told Clayton had been â€œlet go.â€Â  When the caller pressed for a reason, the receptionist replied, â€œWell, she misappropriated funds so we let her go.â€Â  The second defamation occurred when a person with whom Clayton had a separate business relationship called the motel to speak with her and was told Clayton had been fired or let loose, and either that she had stolen or embezzled thousands of dollars.[2]
The trial court correctly held that these defamations were not â€œemployment-relatedâ€ and that therefore the ERP exclusion did not negate Ownersâ€™ obligation to indemnify Lands Inn under the CGL policy.Â  While the substance of the defamatory statements was employment-related, that is, the fact that Clayton had been fired and the reason why, the context was not.Â  The information was not being relayed to other employees to explain Claytonâ€™s termination nor was it conveyed to persons such as potential employers who were inquiring about Claytonâ€™s performance as an employee.Â  Instead, the Lands Inn employee gratuitously relayed the information to Claytonâ€™s acquaintance and to her business associate.Â  The employment context was not present here.
We therefore affirm the finding that the defamation claim was covered by Ownersâ€™ policy since it was not within the ERP exclusion.Â  HS Servs., supra; Adams v. ProSource, supra; Frank and Freedus, supra.Â  Our holding that the exclusion does not apply to the defamation claim means that Owners must indemnify Lands Inn for the Clayton general verdict.Â  Frazier, supra.Â  Accordingly, we need not address whether the malicious prosecution claim[3] is within the ERP exclusion.Â  Id.Â  
C.Â  Error in Amount of Indemnification
The order refers to the CGI policyâ€™s $1 million limit several times.Â  In the orderâ€™s final paragraph, however, it requires that Owners indemnify Lands Inn for the full amount of the $1.25 million Clayton verdict.Â  Owners contends this was error in light of the policy limit, and we agree that the $1.25 million reference appears to be a mere scrivenerâ€™s error.Â  We decline to revise this portion of the order on appeal, but do so without prejudice to Ownersâ€™ right to file a Rule 60(a), SCRCP, motion for relief in the circuit court.
D.Â  Other Scrivenersâ€™ Errors
Owners complains that the appealed order and the accompanying judgment form contain several additional clerical errors.Â  Respondents concede these errors exist, but contend that the errors have caused neither prejudice to Owners nor confusion in the circuit court.Â  Owners does not contest respondentsâ€™ contentions.Â  Error without prejudice does not warrant reversal.Â  E.g., Loftis v. SCE&G, 361 S.C. 434, 604 S.E.2d 714 (Ct. App. 2004).
CONCLUSION
We affirm the trial court order holding that Owners must indemnify Lands Inn for the Clayton verdict, without prejudice to Ownersâ€™ right to move pursuant to Rule 60(a), SCRCPÂ  for the correction of the amount to be indemnified.
AFFIRMED.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, and BURNETT, JJ., concur.

[1] Only the malicious prosecution and defamation theories are involved in this appeal, and the only exclusion issue decided is that of the ERP exclusion.Â  There remain unresolved issues concerning the negligence theory, the failure to cooperate exclusion, and equitable estoppel.
[2] The witness was unclear as to the exact words used.
[3] Clayton was arrested, charged, and indicted for â€œBreach of Trust with Fraudulent Intentâ€ in violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-13-230, based on allegations that Clayton took Lands Innâ€™s money while serving as the businessâ€™s manager.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
John Doe, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Richard H. Crooks, M.D., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25987
Heard April 5, 2005 - Filed May 23, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Gregg E. Meyers, of Charleston, and J. David Flowers, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Dewey Oxner and Moffatt McDonald, both of Haynsworth Sinkler, Boyd, of Greenville, for Respondent.
J. Graham Sturgis, Jr., of Charleston, for Amicus Curiae, Darkness to Light. 
      
    
  


JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  In this sexual-abuse action, the circuit court granted summary judgment for Respondent Richard H. Crooks, M.D. (Crooks), holding that the action of Appellant John Doe (Doe) was barred under the statute of limitations.Â  We certified the case pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
This action was commenced in 2002, when Doe was thirty-four years old.Â  He asserts that in 1983, when he was fourteen or fifteen years old, Crooks molested him.Â  
Doe acknowledges that he was aware of the alleged abuse while it was occurring; that he knew at the time that it was wrong; that he immediately began to feel shame; and that he has â€œdealt with this shame since the first time [the abuse] occurred.â€Â  Doe claims, however, that he did not realize the full extent of his injuries until 2001, when he was thirty-three years old.Â  Only then, he claims, did he understand that the molestation caused him to be obsessive about cleanliness, over-protective of his children, and distrustful of others.
The circuit court held that under the statute of limitations, the time for Doe to commence his action had expired.Â  The court therefore granted summary judgment for Crooks.Â  
ISSUE
Whether the circuit court erred in holding that Doeâ€™s action was barred under the statute of limitations.
ANALYSIS
South Carolina Code section 15-3-555,[1] the current statute of limitations for sexual-abuse actions, was adopted in 2001.Â  See 2001 Act No. 102 (effective August 31, 2001).Â  Prior to 2001, the limitations period was provided by sections 15-3-530(5)[2] and 15-3-535.[3]Â  
Ordinarily, a new statute of limitations applies retroactively.[4]Â  However, it cannot operate to revive an action for which the limitations period has already expired.Â  Such a result would violate the defendantâ€™s rights under the Due Process Clause of the South Carolina Constitution.[5]Â  Goff v. Mills, 279 S.C. 382, 386, 308 S.E.2d 778, 780 (1983); U.S. Rubber Co. v. McManus, 211 S.C. 342, 349, 45 S.E.2d 335, 338 (1947); Stoddard v. Owings, 42 S.C. 88, 92, 20 S.E. 25, 26 (1894).
The circuit court held that when section 15-3-555 became the statute of limitations governing sexual-abuse cases, Doeâ€™s cause of action had already lapsed under sections 15-3-530(5) and 15-3-535.Â  We agree.Â  Consequently, whether the action is barred under section 15-3-555 is irrelevant.Â  
Under the discovery rule, the limitations period commences when the plaintiff â€œkn[o]w[s] or by the exercise of reasonable diligence should [know] that he ha[s] a cause of action.â€Â  Â§ 15-3-535.Â  That the injured party may not at that time â€œcomprehend the full extent of the damage is immaterial.â€Â  Dean v. Ruson Corp., 321 S.C. 360, 364, 468 S.E.2d 645, 647 (1996).Â  
As stated above, Doe acknowledges that he was aware of the alleged abuse when it occurred, when he was a fifteen-year-old minor; that he knew at the time that it was wrong; that he immediately felt shame; and that he has â€œdealt with this shameâ€ ever since.Â  Thus, discovery occurred in 1983, when Doe was fifteen years old.Â  See Doe v. R.D., 308 S.C. 139, 417 S.E.2d 541 (1992) (holding that a plaintiff who was aware of sexual abuse when it was occurring should have known at that time that he had a cause of action). 
Under section 15-3-40(1),[6] the limitations period was tolled until Doe reached the age of majority, eighteen.Â  Under section 15-3-535, Doe then had six years to file his action.[7]Â  In other words, Doe needed to file by the time he turned twenty-four.Â  Because he failed to do so, his cause of action lapsed in 1992, nine years before section 15-3-555 was adopted.Â  We therefore need not address whether the action would be barred under section 15-3-555.Â  The action is barred.
CONCLUSION
The statute of limitations prevents Doe from pursuing his action.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment for Crooks is 
 AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, and BURNETT, JJ., concur.

[1] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-555 (Supp. 2003).
[2] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530(5) (1976 and Supp. 2003) (regarding actions arising from injury to the person, among other things).
[3] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-535 (1976 and Supp. 2003) (providing the discovery rule for â€œactions initiated under Section 15-3-530(5)â€).
[4] Statutes of limitations generally apply retroactively because they are remedial in nature.Â  The General Assembly may, of course, express its intent that a new statute of limitations applies only prospectively.Â  Jenkins v. Meares, 302 S.C. 142, 146, 394 S.E.2d 317, 319 (1990); Goff v. Mills, 279 S.C. 382, 386, 308 S.E.2d 778, 780 (1983).Â  No such intent is expressed in section 15-3-555.
[5] S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 5. 
[6] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-40(1) (Supp. 2003).Â  
[7] For actions accruing prior to April 5, 1988, the limitations period is six years in duration.Â  The three-year limitations period now found in the Code applies to actions accruing on or after April 5, 1988.Â  1988 Act No. 432.
